repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Jefes de Hogar (Heads of
            Household) Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Argentina Jefes de
            Hogar Program Project were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            satisfactory, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: (1) The Program, building on previously available
            foundations, was effective to confront poverty in an
            emergency situation. Despite the implementation issues it
            faced, the Program did prevent beneficiaries from falling
            into extreme poverty and successfully reached the poor. Its
            dynamic targeting approach, through self-selection, was
            probably more efficient to reach the poor during the crisis
            than a static measure such as a proxy-means test. (2) During
            times of crisis, a trade-off between orderly expansion of a
            safety net and rapid coverage of the poor might arise. It is
            unclear whether the decision to strengthen cash programs,
            can result in a better crisis response that an integrated
            strategy that relies on investments in social service
            delivery. On the other hand, the reform of the latter may
            take time to produce results and may thus not be a viable
            strategy during the crisis. (2) Maintaining the nominal
            level of the transfer is difficult politically but effective
            to promote the transition to employment. As the economy
            recovered and employment opportunities improved, the
            transfer lost value and the widening gap between its level
            and wages was an incentive for households to find other
            income-generating activities, especially in the formal labor market.

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Jefes de Hogar (Heads of
            Household) Program Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Jefes de Hogar (Heads of Household)
            Program Project (also the Sixth Social Protection Project
            for Argentina) is the workfare part of a social safety net
            launched by Argentina in April 2002 to alleviate the impact
            of rising unemployment due to the worsening economic crisis.
            A stipend of 150 Argentine pesos per month is provided to an
            unemployed head of household in exchange for participation
            in 4 hours of work in a workfare subproject. The four
            project components include the financing of workfare
            subprojects in community services, minor construction,
            repair, expansion, maintenance or remodeling of schools,
            health facilities, basic sanitation facilities, small roads
            and bridges, culverts and canals, community kitchens and
            centers, tourist centers, and low-cost housing. This report
            focuses on the likely negative environmental impacts from
            these subprojects and proposes measures to mitigate them.
            Expected impacts to land and water include soil saturation
            and salinization, water-borne diseases, an altering of the
            lifestyle of affected people, surface and groundwater
            contamination and the reduction of water quality because of
            industrial and farm chemical use, the proliferation of algae
            and undergrowth due to canal and waterway blockage, change
            in the water table due to overuse, disturbance of aquatic
            life, and erosion and sedimentation. Impacts caused by
            constructing secondary roads in areas that receive a lot of
            rain include flooding and erosion because of stripped
            vegetation and inadequate drainage, and sedimentation in
            surface waters. Road construction sites should be carefully
            selected to avoid affecting critical forest areas and animal
            habitats. The report recommends monitoring the nutrient
            level of water, water discharge level, water salinity, water
            use management, the conditions of canals and the drainage
            system, flood controls, the presence of disease vectors,
            erosion control, waste disposal, contaminant treatment,
            measures to protect workers from hazardous substances,
            waterway protections, demographic change in alluvial plains,
            socioeconomic impacts, and institutional and technical
            capacity of the agencies having oversight.

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Jefes de Hogar (Heads of
            Household) Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Jefes de Hogar (Heads of Household)
            Program Project is the workfare part of a social safety net
            launched by Argentina in April 2002 to alleviate the impact
            of rising unemployment due to the worsening economic crisis.
            A stipend of 150 Argentine pesos per month is provided to an
            unemployed head of household in exchange for participation
            in 4 hours of work in a workfare subproject. There are four
            project components. Component 1 comprises workfare
            subprojects in community services, minor construction,
            repair, expansion, maintenance or remodeling of schools,
            health facilities, basic sanitation facilities, small roads
            and bridges, culverts and canals, community kitchens and
            centers, tourist centers, low-cost housing, and on a pilt
            basis, some productive activities. There are two types of
            subprojects: in the first, the program finances a share of
            the cost of materials as well as benficiary payments; and
            the second finances onlt the payment to the benficiaries.
            Component 2 finances project administration. Component 3
            funds supervision of the project's implementation at
            the local level, including the supporting documentation for
            beneficiary registration and the activities in which
            beneficiaries are engaged. Component 4 finances monitoring
            and evaluation of the program.
